o: A snipper of text that describes a page's content; meta tags don't appear on the page itself, but only in the page's source code
A visible tag on the page

q: Where are meta tags placed in the HTML document?

o: An HTML element that specifies the title of a web page, displayed on search engine results pages (SERPs) as the clickable headline
The main heading on the page
A tag that provides a brief summary of a web page, which search engines often display below the title in search results
A tag that tells search engine crawlers which pages or files they can or cannot request from your site
Specifies the character encoding for the HTML document (usually UTF-8)

q: What is the 'Viewport' meta tag used for?
o: To control the layout on mobile browsers (essential for responsive design)

What is the recommended length for a Meta Description?
What does 'noindex' value in robots meta tag do?
o: Tells search engines not to try to index the page
Tells search engines to index the page immediately

q: What does 'nofollow' value in robots meta tag do?
o: Tells search engines not to follow the links on this page
Tells users not to click links
An HTML link element with standard syntax <link rel="canonical" href="URL" /> that tells engines which URL is the master version

q: Why is the Canonical tag important?
o: It prevents duplicate content issues by specifying the 'preferred' version of a web page

q: What is 'Alt Text' (referenced often with meta tags)?
o: Text within an image tag that describes the image for accessibility and SEO
A protocol that allows any web page to become a rich object in a social graph (used by Facebook, LinkedIn, etc.)
The title of your object as it should appear within the graph (e.g., in a Facebook post)
An image URL which should represent your object within the graph
Meta tags specific to Twitter that control how content is displayed when shared on Twitter
The type of card to be created (e.g., summary, summary_large_image)
A deprecated tag where you list keywords; Google no longer uses it for web ranking
Specifies the character encoding for the document (older way, charset is modern)
Identifies the author of the Web page
Defines the copyright owner of the document
Redirects the user to a new URL after a certain amount of time (not recommended for SEO)
Used to label the maturity rating of content (e.g., adult)
Specifies the date the content was created or modified
Specifies the language of the content (usually handled by <html lang=''> attribute now)
Indicates the software used to generate the document (e.g., WordPress)

q: Is the 'Generator' tag needed for SEO?

A collaborative, community activity with a mission to create, maintain, and promote schemas for structured data on the Internet

q: Does Schema markup replace meta tags?
o: No, they work together. Schema provides structured data, meta tags provide page-level metadata.

q: What happens if you have duplicate Title tags?
o: It confuses search engines about which page is relevant for a query, often diluting potential rankings

q: What happens if you have duplicate Meta Descriptions?
o: Search engines may see it as duplicate content or lazy optimization, potentially ignoring them

q: Can you put meta tags in the body?
o: Generally no, they should be in the <head>. Browsers might move them or ignore them if found in body.
Specifies the base URL and/or target for all relative URLs in a document (technically not a meta tag, but head element)

Used to support Pingback (automatic notifications when other sites link to you), often used in blogs
Links to an alternate version of the document (e.g. print, translations, feeds)

links to a short url for the page (e.g. wp.me/p123)

q: What is the order of meta tags in head?
